DOC.brief_summary: 1 . Design develop web-based self-management intervention improve catheter-related outcome quality life people spinal cord injury ( SCI ) . 2 . Conduct pilot study assess feasibility ( i.e. , acceptability usability website application ) preliminary effectiveness new self-management intervention . 3 . Develop test reliability new/modified measure ( intermittent catheter self-efficacy self-management ) .
DOC.brief_title: Internet Self-Management People With Intermittent Urinary Catheters
DOC.detailed_description: Stages involve : ( 1 ) Develop Internet-based intervention improve self-management outcome related clean intermittent catheterization ( CIC ) among people SCI ( 2 ) Pretest Internet application five person SCI use CIC ; ( 3 ) Conduct web-based six-month intervention pilot study group 30 SCI use CIC . Outcomes : catheter-related adverse health outcome ( e.g. , UTI , urine leakage ) , CIC self- management , CIC self-efficacy , health related expenditure quality life . Information study use modify Internet application future Phase 2 trial large study .
DOC.criteria: Individuals include English speaking adult 18 year SCI interest participate . Inclusion criterion : 1. use CIC regular bladder drainage , 2. expect use CIC indefinitely least nine month , 3. access ability use computer telephone . Computer telephone use may voice activate little hand use . Study participant need perform CIC entirely , people limit hand dexterity may caregivers procedure . They need able use computer telephone however . Additional inclusion criterion five person `` intervention pretesting group '' ( describe III , 1 ) include : 1. use CIC regular bladder drainage least one year 2. expect use CIC indefinitely least one year . People need use CIC least year well experienced CIC two Peer Leaders select group . People exclude communicate English , Are terminally ill , expect discontinue CIC within next nine month . NonEnglish speaking people include translated instrument ( e.g. , Spanish ) available measure part small study might compromise integrity first test preliminary effectiveness .
